title: U.S.-Stock Funds Fell 3.0% in the Month
text:
Fund investors survived the Month of Tweets with moderate damage.

There were days during the month, as U.S./China trade tensions flared, when it looked like it would be uglier. But the markets continue to show resilience.

U.S.-stock funds declined by an average of 3.0% for August, and are still up 16.6% for the year so far, according to Thomson Reuters Lipper data. International-stock funds eased 2.0%, to trim their year-to-date advance to 10.3%.

“It was definitely volatile…. A lot of it was about tweets,” says Sal Bruno, chief investment officer of IndexIQ, a subsidiary of New York Life Investments. But the larger issue is the conflicting views about the economy. Consumer confidence and employment look good, but other variables point to an economic slowdown. “Which is going to win out? It’s complete uncertainty,” says Mr. Bruno.

Some of the old rules about the economy and markets don’t seem to be working now. “People have been assuming that for yields to go down, you need an economic slowdown,” says Robert Tipp, chief investment strategist and head of global bonds at PGIM Fixed Income. But U.S. interest rates have fallen, driven more in recent years by secular trends like aging demographics and other trends—including the negative interest rates infecting the rest of the world.

Those actions by non-U.S. central banks to cut rates to the bone, says Mr. Tipp, feels “a little like a medieval visit to the doctor, where they want to help but they’re basically killing the patient, taxing their savings and investments with negative rates, and then hoping it will stimulate the economy. It doesn’t make any sense.”

A surge in bond prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields, helped bond funds rise in August. Funds focusing on intermediate-maturity, investment-grade debt, the most common type of bond fund, were up 2.3% for the month and are showing a 9.0% total return so far this year.

Many investors are focusing now on the Federal Reserve’s policy-making meeting next week, when it could cut rates again. But Mr. Tipp says the Fed “is a bit of a sideshow” these days. “Whatever the Fed does will be overwhelmed by the secular forces like demographics, and what is going on in the rest of the world—especially subzero yields taking hold in the other major bond markets."

Adds Mr. Bruno: “People love rate cuts—up to a point. No one wants to see negative rates here like the rest of the world.”

Mr. Power is a Wall Street Journal news editor in South Brunswick, N.J. Email him at william.power@wsj.com.
description: Monthly Monitor: U.S.-stock funds at the end of August were still up 16.6% for the year, according to Thomson Reuters Lipper data.
